Title: 2533/JN - Arbitrary Waveform Generator
Description:
The Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of Sheffield, with funding from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) requires an electrical waveform generator capable of producing arbitrary waveforms at GHz frequencies, and pulses of sub-nanosecond duration. The equipment will be used in two scenarios: a) creation of picosecond electrical pulses to drive an electro-optical modulator, in order to convert a continuous wave laser into an arbitrary pulsed source; b) creation of complex electrical pulse sequences for microwave-frequency manipulation of electrical charges in semiconductor quantum dots.

This is an non-EU open exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffield

If you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender they must be submitted via the In-tend system, this can be accessed at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffield

Completed tenders must be returned through the same e-tendering system.

Title: Framework Agreements for the Maintenance, Supply and Installation of Personal Home Stair Lifts and Through Ceiling Lifts
Description:
Knowsley Metropolitan Borough Council is looking to establish a Framework Agreement for the Maintenance, Supply and Installation of Personal Home Stair Lifts and Through Ceiling Lifts. The framework agreement is for the supply, installation, servicing, maintenance, removal and re-installation of personal home lifts that improve the access to facilities for disabled people with sensory and mobility loss. The supply and installation work will be carried out in both private owner occupied and housing association properties. The servicing and maintenance will be carried out in private owner occupier's household properties. A small number of other items are serviced in respite services and in shared lives homes.\r
\r
Lot 1 - is for maintenance and annual servicing of stair lifts, maintenance and bi-annual servicing of through ceiling lifts and step-lifts and maintenance and bi-annual servicing and Lift Operations and Lifting Equipment Regulations 1998 (LOLER) testing of ceiling track hoists and includes the removal, storage, refurbishment and re-installation of all the same items.\r
\r
Lot 2 - is for the supply and installation of new curved and straight stair lifts.\r
\r
Lot 3 - is for the supply and installation of new through ceiling lifts and step lifts.

Title: QU345 - Birmingham Poverty Truth Commission  - AWARD
Description:
The Council requires a supplier for the establishment and provision of "The Birmingham Poverty Truth Commission". 
      
      The aim of this project is to build on the legacy of the previous truth commission and develop a new model to become a rolling engagement model that strengthens the connection between the Council and its city partners and the citizens. 
      
      The provider organisation will be expected to work in collaboration with key stakeholders, including the local citizens, the Council, the Creating a City without Inequality Forum partners, the Birmingham Financial Inclusion Partnership and others, as appropriate as well as an academic partner. The academic partner may be sub-contracted by the provider, or other arrangements may be put in place to secure their involvement and delivery of a robust evaluation of the project and operating model of the truth commission.
      
      The provider is expected to cover the expenses for testifying commissioners and ensure that meetings are held in neutral safe spaces that are accessible and provide environments for private conversations which cannot be overheard as well as space for more open group discussions.
      
      The recruitment of the commissioners is a fundamental part of the process and key to the success of the commission and it is vital that the provider recruits people who understand the commission, what it is seeking to do and what is being asked of them. Commissioners will need to have a personal commitment to addressing poverty, inequality, and exclusion, and a desire to work together with others to that end. 
      
      Commissioners will need to be people who have things to say and stories to tell. Their stories need to come out of their lived experience of inequality and the topic focus of the commission cycle. They should understand how their experiences relate to others in their community and their city.

Title: QU341 - Faith-based Communities support for Covid-19 Campaign  - AWARD
Description:
Public Health Division is inviting organisations from faith-based organisations to apply for funding to provide COVID-19 and Test and Trace messages to the communities they support throughout Birmingham, either separately or as part of a partnership consortium/ consortia bid. Islam is the 2nd most popular faith in Birmingham next to Christian. This is closely followed by Sikh and Hindu.
      
      We are seeking tenders for the following faith-based communities:
      
      Lot A - Islam
      Lot B - Sikhism
      Lot C - Hinduism
      Lot D - African led churches and African Caribbean led churches
      Lot E - Interfaith small faith communities
         
      Tenders will require organisations to support citizens from these faiths and to be shared through interfaith organisations to ensure COVID-19 and Test and Trace messages are shared as widely as possible through trusted resources across all communities throughout Birmingham. It is anticipated that more than one provider will be required for this Lot. Partnership bids will also be welcome.
      
      Timeframe for delivery: The Public Health Division will discuss the exact timescales once tenders are evaluated. We anticipate that the programme will last no longer than 7 months, however, should COVID 19 outbreak remain a significant issue beyond the contract period, we reserve the right to extend the operations under this contract for further 3 months.

Title: Staff Surveys- University of Derby
Description:
Human Resources at the University of Derby would like to run an organisational wide staff survey to better understand the perception of our staff. Measuring perceptions and capturing the employee voice underpins our people strategy. 

The survey will enable us to identify areas of good practice and pinpoint any areas for concern. We can then focus on themes or areas of greatest need, implementing mitigating strategies to springboard staff engagement and organisational performance. The University has run a staff engagement survey over the last 12 years, with an average of 70% response rate. HR works alongside Leaders and Managers with the results.

We are looking for suitable supplier to work with us to deliver a full staff experience survey, looking at organisation with a robust question set and benchmarking ability both in the sector and external.

Notice Identifier: Understanding the lived experiences of those approaching later life
Title: Understanding the lived experiences of those approaching later life
Description:
The Centre for Ageing Better's strategy, which launched in the summer of 2018, reiterates our determination to create a society where everyone enjoys their later life. In order to achieve this goal, we are taking a preventative approach and focusing on those approaching later life (approximately people aged 50-69).

This piece of work is an important step in our organisational development. It is the first time we are tendering for a large, mixed methods piece of research that will explore in detail this life stage (there are two elements to the project with a total value of Â£180,000 excluding VAT).

The research will give us an overview of experiences, looking across our priority goal areas, as well as provide us with rich narratives that illustrate people's stories. The results will shape our work programmes going forward, provide us with invaluable insights that will strengthen our dissemination and influencing activities, and support others who are also interested in this exploring this life stage. 

Deadline - 5pm, 16 August

Title: The production of As Fitted record drawings of the Medical Gas Pipeline Systems at Kettering General Hospital.
Description:
A requirement of HTM02-01 and the Pressure System Safety Regulations is that the estates department should have accurate and up to date drawings of the MGPS showing main sections and branches, departments served, control valves, terminal units and alarm systems for each medical gas service. A schematic diagram of the installation should also be provided.
In addition to this each isolating valve and AVSU should be individually identified by a unique reference number. The appropriate reference number, corresponding to that shown on the drawings, should be displayed at or on each isolating valve. The drawing should indicate the type and make of terminal units.
The Trust therefore requires fixed costs for the following:
1.	Provision of a full set of 'As-Fitted' drawings of the medical gas pipeline systems
2.	A full set of schematic drawings of each medical gas system including AGSS
3.	A full set of isometric drawings of each medical gas system including flow rates
4.	Each isolating valve and AVSU to be fitted with a Traffolyte tag/label with a unique reference number and in accordance to HTM02-01 Appendix K.
5.	Install new valve locks to existing Line valves.
6.	Verify all existing AVSU keys and replace any missing as required.
7.	Provide 2 x new key cabinets (1 x for AVSU and 1 x for Line Valves) complete with an AVSU and Valve schedule. The schedule should correspond to AVSU & valve numbers entered on the drawings.
8.	Marked up department drawings at each AVSU showing what is connected to the AVSU's to assist with emergency situations/shut downs

Title: Pseudo Dynamic Purchasing System - Individual Service Fund Provider List
Description:
An Individual Service Fund (or ISF) is when an organisation manages a Personal Budget on behalf an individual with care and support needs, and helps them to decide how and when they want care and support to meet assessed outcomes. 
Within an Individual Service Fund (ISF): 
> An individual's Personal Budget is paid to, and is held by, an organisation (the ISF Provider) for the provision of care and support

 > The individual (or their representative) with the help of the ISF Provider, decides how to spend their Personal Budget to meet their assessed care and support needs and outcomes. 

> The ISF Provider is accountable to the individual (as well as to the Council). 

> The ISF Provider commits to spend the money only on the individual's service and the management and support necessary to provide that service 

An ISF Provider can deliver some or all of the services required to meet the individual's assessed care and support needs and outcomes. Where an organisation does not deliver all the services, they can work with the individual to outsource to another organisation or support them to purchase equipment, employ Personal Assistants, or arrange other types of support. 

This procurement is to appoint organisations wishing to offer Individual Service Funds to Wakefield Council's accredited ISF Provider List.

Title: QU339 - Children and Young People's messages for Covid-19 Campaign  - AWARD
Description:
COVID-19 has disrupted the life of every child. The UK government has implemented measures to tackle this serious public health crisis, including closing schools (except for children of key workers and the most vulnerable children who have social workers) and enforcing social distancing. However, it is important to recognise the impact on children and young people, particularly those in low-income families or living in poverty. School closures, while an important way to stave the spread of COVID-19, may have resulted in increased social isolation for young people. 
      
      Government guidance advocating social distancing and social isolation for those that are unwell, may lead to increased feelings of loneliness among children and young people which is already an issue and may negatively impact on their wellbeing. Returning to school may also have its own issues for children and young people. 
      
      Children of different age groups have differing needs and complexity of receiving messages to support:
      â¢         awareness and understanding of COVID-19, 
      â¢         access to testing
      â¢         knowledge of how to respond if they test positive or told they are a contact of a case, 
      â¢         knowledge of how to reduce risk factors associated with increased risk of severe illness or death from COVID-19
      
      To better support the needs of the differing age groups this tender has been broken into Children and Young People categories:
      
      Lot A:            Early Years
      Lot B:            Primary
      Lot C:           Secondary
      Lot D:           Young People under 25 years to encompass those in receipt of benefits
      
      We are seeking applicant organisations to highlight relevant and innovative methods they intend to adopt to enable information to be shared with children and young people using appropriate methods according to their age groups. This may be through social media or other relevant resources as required, digital or non digital. It is important that the needs of all children across Birmingham is considered in this tender. 
      
      The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. You will then be sent details on how to log on which will enable you to download all relevant quotation documentation.  
      
      If you are unable to register with In-tend or have any questions or problems on how to use this web site please either email us at: cps@birmingham.gov.uk or call CPS Helpdesk on 0121 464 8000.
      
      Your completed quotation submission should be returned by noon on 10th September 2020 via the 'in-tend' system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc

Title: GB-Poole: Asbestos Management Consultancy Services
Description:
Dorset HealthCare University NHS FT requires a suitably qualified and competent asbestos consultancy that can undertake the following specialised services in order for the Trust to be compliant with the Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012.  
      The services include but are not limited to:- New Surveys, Re-inspection surveys, Management and Refurbishment & Demolition Asbestos Surveys, Production of Asbestos Management Plans, Asbestos Awareness and Management Training, Project Management, Analytical Services and Asbestos Consultancy over a fixed term basis of 3 + 2 years. 
      The asbestos management consultant will work with the Trust to support the planned maintenance and development of the existing Infrastructure together with assistance in Strategic Development over a period of forthcoming growth and expansion.

Title: Provision of consultancy services to develop a Newbury Town Centre masterplan and Supplementary Planning Document (SPD). - AWARD
Description:
This commission seeks a specialist multi-disciplinary consultancy team to produce a SPD for Newbury Town Centre which addresses a series of specific challenges and takes advantage of emerging opportunities to reposition the town's commercial, leisure and residential offer and ensure it continues to meet the needs of existing and future town users.
                    Work will include:
                  - Research and analysis, 
                  - Visioning, 
                  - Stakeholder engagement, and 
                  - Production of draft and final reports.
      The successful bidder will need to illustrate that they have the creative drive to address the challenges and provide an imaginative, innovative and inspiring vision that can be translated into tangible deliverable projects. The bidder should have the commercial acumen and creative insight to address the challenges identified and will need to demonstrate expertise and experience across the following core disciplines detailed in the Specification. Title: QU338 - Health messages for Covid-19 Campaign  - AWARD
Description:
Public Health Division is inviting organisations, separately or as part of a partnership consortium / consortia) to provide information to citizens who have existing health conditions to enable them to: 
      o understand their perspectives of COVID-19, 
      o help them access support to better manage their health conditions and reduce risk,
      o provide networks for early awareness and intervention if there are increased concerns around subsequent waves of COVID-19.
      
      Successful applicants will ensure appropriate messages are shared with citizens through innovative approaches both through non-digital and digital platforms, particularly during an outbreak of COVID-19. The provider(s) will be required to have relevant information translated into appropriate community languages, linking to the other community-based services. It is important to the success of the project that providers work together to ensure that messages can be shared with citizens from relevant communities with information translated into appropriate community languages and shared through trusted community-based providers. Providers will also be expected to actively support the Birmingham City Council Public Health BHealthy campaign.
      
      Specific Groups to prevent people catching COVID-19, responses and Test and Trace messages:
      
      Lot A:   Stroke
      Lot B:   Diabetes
      Lot C:  High Blood Pressure
      Lot D: Chronic Kidney Disease
      Lot E:  COPD
      Lot F:   Obese - BMI over 30
      Lot G:  Cardiovascular Disease (CVD)
      
      The Council will be using its free to use e-tendering system (in-tend) for the administration of this procurement process and potential suppliers must register with the system to be able to express an interest. If you wish to express an interest in this opportunity please click on the following link to access https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register. You will then be sent details on how to log on which will enable you to download all relevant quotation documentation.

Title: London and Quadrant Housing Trust - Acoustic Consultants Framework 2020 - 2024 - AWARD
Description:
London and Quadrant Housing Trust and its subsidiary Quadrant Construction Services are one of the largest providers of affordable housing in the UK, housing over 250,000 people in more than 95,000 homes, primarily across London and the South East of England. London and Quadrant Housing Trust are tendering for the provision of Acoustic Consultants for London and Quadrant's Self Delivered New Build Projects to comply with the Public Contracts regulations 2015. The objective of this tender process is to establish a Framework Agreement with the tenderers and London and Quadrant Housing Trust. The dates and contract value are estimates and could be subject to change. This is tender is for Consultants only. 
      
      This is a two stage tender and both stages adhere to the time-scales as prescribed within the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 for Restricted OJEU Tenders.
      
      Stage 1: Selection Stage
      
      Click on the 'Express Interest' Button at the bottom
      
      Click on the 'Selection Stage' Tab at the top
      - Scroll to the bottom of the screen and you will be able to view the Tender Documents and access the Standard Selection Questionnaire
      - For the Selection Stage you will only need to submit the Standard Selection Questionnaire
      - We will score your questionnaire and will advise you as to whether you are successful or not
      - Pricing Documents will only be available to those who have passed the Selection Stage
      
      
      ONLY IF YOU HAVE PASSED THE SELECTION STAGE 
      
      Stage 2: ITT Stage
      
      - Click on the 'ITT' Tab 
      - Scroll to the bottom and you will be able to access the Tender Documents
      - Tenderers will be briefed as to what they will need to submit for this tender
      
      Please allow sufficient time to submit your return by the specified dates as late returns will not be permitted. 
      
      
      Under the Framework Agreement L&Q and all companies within the L&Q Group (including, without limitation, Quadrant Construction Services) will have the option to call-off contracts with individual framework contractors as and when required. In addition, other Social Housing Providers in the UK (both those that are in existence now and those that may be in existence in the future) will also be entitled to call-off contracts under the Framework Agreement. "Social Housing Provider" for this purpose means any provider of social housing and includes, without limitation, Registered Providers, Local Authorities and ALMOs. Such Social Housing Providers will only be entitled to call off under the Framework Agreement if L&Q consents.
      
      For information regarding this tender please contact the Framework Team via the tender portal. This tender is managed by the Framework Buying department. Please do not contact any other department within the London and Quadrant Group. Please do not contact Group Procurement for information as this Tender has been created by the Framework Buying Department.

Title: 2623/488/MY/NAMRC/20 3D Printed Electronics System (3DPES) - AWARD
Description:
2623/488/MY/NAMRC/20        3D Printed Electronics System (3DPES)
      
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a 3D Printed Electronics System (3DPES) on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Nuclear Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.
      
      Scope of Requirement
      The Nuclear AMRC (NAMRC) Digital Controls and Instrumentation Group have a need to develop a capability for rapid prototyping of electronic device designs. Developing this capability will support the strategic aim of the NAMRC to provide a world class agile digital product prototyping service and demonstrate to industry the opportunities for integrated agile digital product design in electronics.
      
      The technology identified to support this agile prototyping of complex electronic device designs is 3D Printed Electronics prototyping System (3DPES). This equipment shall provide a self-contained standalone capability demonstrating additively manufactured prototyping of Printed Electronics with highly complex 3D circuits.
      
      
      Tender Process and Documentation:
      This procurement is an open procedure conducted in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015
      
      The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield
      
      If you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender they must be submitted via the In-tend System, this can be accessed at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield
      
      Completed tenders must be returned through the same e-tendering system.
      
      Closing date for receipt of tenders: 3rd August at 12 Noon (UK time).

Organisation Name: NHS NORTH EAST LINCOLNSHIRE CLINICAL COMMISSIONING GROUP
Title: Voluntary and Community Sector Infrastructure Support
Description:
The North East Lincolnshire Clinical Commissioning Group (NELCCG) in conjunction with North East Lincolnshire Council (NELC) wishes to continue and evolve the existing provision for Voluntary and Community Sector Infrastructure Support in the borough of North East Lincolnshire.  

In consultation with local community based organisations and local providers NELCCG and NELC are looking to source a provider or consortium of providers to deliver infrastructure support to local voluntary and community sector organisations.

The Contract will be initially set from 1st April 2020 till 31st March 2023  with the possibility of extending the term beyond the initial contracted duration by up to 2 [two] years with mutual agreement from the Provider and NELCCG. This would be dependent on successful achievement of contract outcomes and funding available to support the contract from commissioners.

It is likely TUPE will apply to the transfer of staff undertaking the current service provision; however, it will be the responsibility of bidders to seek appropriate legal advice at the appropriate time. 

Interested parties wishing to participate in the Procurement should register and download a tender pack on NELCCG e-procurement system https://eprocurement.northeastlincolnshireccg.nhs.uk/ and submit an application using the supplied documentation.

The deadline for receipt of completed tenders is 12 noon on Friday 13th December 2019.
Additional Text:
NELCCG Eprocurement

https://eprocurement.northeastlincolnshireccg.nhs.uk/procurements

Interested Bidders are to register on NELCCG's e-procurement system via https://eprocurement.northeastlincolnshireccg.nhs.uk/. Registration does not require approval and will provide instant access to the tender pack.

DFID is seeking a Supplier to deliver its trade development and facilitation programme,  to improve trade performance and customs in the OPTs.  The programme is designed to be flexible and adaptable, and will work politically and technically to:

      -	Improve the capacity of Palestinian trade related institutions and the trade enabling environment 
      -	Strengthen the competiveness of the private sector to export and create jobs

Title: Service Management Partner  - AWARD
Description:
WYCA is looking for a Service Management Partner who can provide guidance on all areas of the ITIL framework and agree an implementation approach for each. As ITIL is so broad it may be the case that the selected supplier allocates different specialists for different parts of the framework.
      In addition to providing service management expertise, the Service Management Partner will provide PRINCE2 management, the Combined Authority will provide a Project Assistant to give support and internal co-ordination. The partner will be required to deliver a PID within three weeks of the project commencing which will require sign-off from the ICT Management Board which this project reports to.
      Much of this work will involve engagement with senior Combined Authority staff outside ICT Services to develop essential service management requirements such as service and operational level agreements. Here, the Service Management Partner will confidently lead workshops with heads of service and directors whilst closely involving ICT Services staff. 
      Although it is not expected that the partner will write every SLA and OLA, they will lead the production of an agreed selection, train and develop Combined Authority staff to continue this work using their recommended approach and then have overall responsibility for the completion of the remaining agreements which will be delegated to Combined Authority staff under the partner's direction.
      It is important that the Service Management Partner is pragmatic and adaptable. The Combined Authority requires practical help with the introduction of service management techniques which will make a visible and rapid difference to how ICT services are delivered. The Combined Authority does not want a partner to undertake a theoretical exercise or to expand on the benefits of service management.

Title: Kings Walk Park Play Equipment - Leicester Forest East Parish Council
Description:
Requirements:

Leicester Forest East Parish Council are seeking a contractor to design, supply and install a dynamic and inclusive range of play equipment on their Kings walk Park. 

Detailed designs are required at the levels of circa Â£40,000, Â£60,000 and Â£80,000 for comparison.

The quotations must include removal of all spoils/rubbish and a welfare unit should be supplied and collected.

A site meeting is a requirement.

Safety:

All equipment must comply with any applicable legislation and RoSPA requirements and appropriate warranties must be supplied. 

The contractor shall provide evidence that they can meet the requirements of the CDM Regulations and any necessary risk assessments, and method statements must be provided.

All precautions to protect the integrity of the site and adjoining paths, car park and properties must be taken. The public must not have access to any of the contractor's items and materials being used as part of the contract. The contractor shall safeguard the works with temporary barricading of a "Heras" type of at least 2 metres in height. The fence panels shall be constructed so that they deter climbing and will be anchored into freestanding concrete/rubber blocks, the panels locked to prevent unauthorised access. The fence to be installed before commencement of works and removed from the site following completion of all works including ground reinstatements.

Please submit tenders by e-mail and hard copy marked 'Kings Walk Play Equipment Tender' to:

Title: Market research services to support the Initial Teacher Training (ITT) recruitment marketing campaign
Description:
The Department is seeking a market research agency to undertake market research for the Get IntoTeaching marketing campaign, which seeks to raise the status of teaching, drive motivation to become a teacher and provide support and advice to train. The campaign is long-standing, dating back to the 1990s, and last year entered an exciting new era with the launch of a new strategic and creative approach. 
The campaign consists of a range of owned, earned and paid-for channels, including AV, print, radio, media partnerships and extensive social and digital advertising. This is supported by a comprehensive programme of events and CRM to encourage and support people to apply, including providing access to one-to-one support from a nominated adviser and school experience days.  

Objectives: 

To support the campaign in making a significant contribution to the fulfilment of ITT targets by:

1. Evaluating the success of the current campaign 
2. Informing future creative development 
3. Developing understanding of our audience and the customer journey 
4. Informing the audience and marketing strategies for emerging policy initiatives and priorities

Organisation Name: NEW ANGLIA LOCAL ENTERPRISE PARTNERSHIP LIMITED
Title: New Anglia Peer Network Programme
Description:
This invitation sets out the requirements for the delivery of facilitation and one to one support as part of the implementation of the New Anglia Peer Network Programme, funded by the Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy (BEIS), to deliver a series of Peer Networks, with cohorts of eleven people, through the New Anglia Growth Hub, consisting of owners and/or managers from the SME business community participating in each network.  

The Programme will see the creation of a series of peer networks (cohorts) through the Growth Hub network, with each group consisting of 11 owners or managers from the SME business community participating in each network.  Led by an experienced Facilitator, these Peer Networks will typically meet fortnightly as part of delivering 18 hours of action learning through 2-3-hour sessions.  Individual one-to-one support (coaching, mentoring, or advice) will also be provided directly by the Programme, to help to implement and manage change.  Active involvement in the Peer Network will enhance the leadership capabilities, knowledge and confidence of business owners and entrepreneurs within a local region.  It will help build regional connectivity and strength within the SME business community.

To ensure successful delivery the facilitator has three main strands of responsibility:

â¢	Management and direction of their individual peer network(s) and its successful facilitation using the principles of action learning 

â¢	Individual one-to-one communication with each participant to support reflection and provide signposting to the most appropriate local support

â¢	The capture of information, data, and insight to help inform contract manager and programme about frequent hot topics for delegates
Attachments: Peer to Peer Consultancy Tender Specification 27-08-20.pdf Peer Networks - Playbook - V1 August 2020.pdf Peer Networks - Playbook - V1 August 2020.pdf

Title: AREA 4 20/21 MALTON FOOTWAYS R&R
Description:
Treatment of the footways and carriageway on U329 Maiden Greve. Works consist of 20mm, 30mm and 70mm deep footway resurfacing including replacement of damaged kerbs along inner curve of carriageway, raising low kerbs at footway crossings and replacement/resetting of iron works, and one section of carriageway patching/reprofiling at a failed area of carriageway.

Treatment of the footways and carriageway on U332 Middlecave Road. Works consist of 70mm deep footway resurfacing, replacement of damaged kerbs along inner curve of carriageway, replacement of service covers, installation of edging kerbs, re-setting of channels, replacement of kerbs and reprofiling carriageway at uncontrolled crossing, and resurfacing at 50mm deep of a vehicle access at the school.

Treatment of the footways and carriageway on U336 Mount Crescent. Works to include kerb replacement and footway re-surfacing at 20mm and 100mm depths, carriageway patching at 100mm deep and reinstatement/refreshing of road markings between the traffic signals at Newbiggin junction to Middlecave Road junction.

Treatment of the footways on U362 Orchard Road. Works consist of 20mm and 70mm deep footway resurfacing, replacement of damaged kerbs, raise low kerbs at driveway crossings and repair damaged footways at driveway crossings, and installation of edging kerbs. Also included is perforation of a section of footpath and reinstatement to a grassed area at Bramble Walk and construction of 220mm deep Type 1 footway to replace the removed section along the edge of carriageway. Description:
Queen Street, Scarborough:
Plane off 120mm of existing bituminous carriageway surfacing on Queen Street, Resurface with 20mm SAMI layer and 2 x 50mm HRA 35/14 WTR 2 surface course. 14/20 PCC 65 PSV (top layer only). Total Area in Queen Street is 2,148m2.
11m of sandstone kerbing to replace on Queen Street.
New thermoplastic road markings shall be applied throughout the extents of the scheme. Ironworks shall be adjusted to suit carriageway levels or as directed by the engineer.

Newborough/ Eastborough, Scarborough:
Plane off 120mm of existing bituminous carriageway surfacing on Newborough / Eastborough, Resurface with 20mm SAMI layer and 2 x 50mm HRA 35/14 WTR 2 surface course 14/20 PCC 65 PSV (top layer only). The area of this section is 2,976m2. The 50m approach to the Stop line at the bottom end of Eastborough to be laid in 68PSV (212m2). Total Area in Newborough and Eastborough is 3,188m2.
New thermoplastic road markings shall be applied throughout the extents of the scheme. Ironworks shall be adjusted to suit carriageway levels or as directed by the engineer.
The Grand Total area for both sections is 5,336m2
The Contractor shall allow in his programme for all milled surfaces to be inspected by the Engineer during daylight hours, in order that any areas of defective concrete or sub-base can be identified and remedial measures designed and implemented in advance of laying any SAMI or Binder courses.
The Contractor shall make available during the day following any pavement milling, any such plant. materials, and labour that might reasonably be anticipated to be required to enable remedial works to be undertaken to defective concrete or other sub-base prior to the commencement of night works.
Core results indicate the depth to concrete varies significantly throughout the scheme extents so the surfacing material and thickness of layers may change after the Engineer has inspected the concrete and sub-base areas after the milling has been completed.

Title: Communications Qualitative Research
Description:
The Department for Education (DfE) is responsible for children's services and education in England, including early years, children's social care, schools, higher and further education policy, apprenticeships and wider skills. Our ambitious goal is to provide world-class education, training and care for everyone, whatever their background. 
The DfE Communications Directorate contributes to this ambition by driving changes in awareness, attitudes and behaviours through effective communication with multiple external audiences, such as parents, teachers, school leaders and governors, children's social workers, businesses, and young people. Our work cuts across all areas related to DfE strategic priorities, including post-16 and skills development, schools, and children's safety and wellbeing.
Insight and evaluation are at the heart of all government communications. The Government Communication Service (GCS) advocates the use of robust audience insight to ensure communications are relevant, meaningful and effective. An in-depth understanding of our key audiences (including their attitudes, habits and preferences) is integral to identifying the role for communications as a lever for change and the design and implementation of effective communications strategies. It is also vital that we evaluate our communications to understand what is and what is not working, and learn from that to improve effectiveness.
We are therefore looking to establish a four-year (2+1+1) call-off qualitative research contract to generate actionable audience insight and contribute to the evaluation of our communications.

Title: Communications Quantitative Research
Description:
The Department for Education (DfE) is responsible for children's services and education in England, including early years, children's social care, schools, higher and further education policy, apprenticeships and wider skills. Our ambitious goal is to provide world-class education, training and care for everyone, whatever their background. 
The DfE Communications Directorate contributes to this ambition by driving changes in awareness, attitudes and behaviours through effective communication with multiple external audiences, such as parents, teachers, school leaders and governors, children's social workers, businesses, and young people. Our work cuts across all areas related to DfE strategic priorities, including post-16 and skills development, schools, and children's safety and wellbeing.
Insight and evaluation are at the heart of all government communications. The Government Communication Service (GCS) advocates the use of robust audience insight to ensure communications are relevant, meaningful and effective. An in-depth understanding of our key audiences (including their attitudes, habits and preferences) is integral to identifying the role for communications as a lever for change and the design and implementation of effective communications strategies. It is also vital that we evaluate our communications to understand what is and what is not working, and learn from that to improve effectiveness.

Organisation Name: NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS Southport and Formby CCG and NHS South Sefton CCG - Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT)
Description:
NHS Southport and Formby CCG and NHS South Sefton CCG - Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT)

NHS Midlands and Lancashire Commissioning Support Unit (CSU) are awarding this contract on behalf of NHS Southport & Formby CCG and NHS South Sefton CCG who wish to procure an IAPT (Improving Access to Psychological Therapies) service for patients living in the CCG area.  

The aim of the service is to improve access to psychological therapies for the populations of Southport & Formby CCG and South Sefton CCG and provide timely interventions, delivered from accessible community venues that will improve mental health and wellbeing.  The provider will be required to deliver interventions at step 2, 3 of the stepped care model in accordance to NICE guidelines, using validated evidence-based assessment monitoring and outcome tools. Also, as part of a local initiative step 4 will be delivered.

The delivery of steps 2 and 3 of the stepped-care model as defined in the IAPT Manual which will be delivered by a multi-disciplinary team which will be delivered within the following nationally defined modes of delivery:
1.	Core IAPT; and
2.	IAPT-LTC (Long Term Conditions)
Contact Address 1: c/o NHS South Sefton CCG, 3rd Floor Merton House
Additional Text:
This contract award is for Social and other specific services which are Light Touch Regime services for the purpose of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 as specified in Schedule 3 of the Regulations ('Regulations') http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/102/schedule/3/made

Accordingly, the Contracting Authority is only bound by those parts of the Regulations detailed in Chapter 3 Particular Procurement Regimes Section 7 http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/102/part/2/chapter/3/made


The Contracting Authority is not voluntarily following any other part of the Regulations.

As the CCG is a relevant body for the purpose of the National Health Service (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No 2) Regulations 2013 these Regulations also apply to this procurement.
Right to Cancel: The Contracting Authority reserves the right to discontinue the procurement process at any time, which shall include the right not to award a contract or contracts, and does not bind itself to accept the lowest tender, or any tender received, and reserves the right to award a contract in part, or to call for new tenders should it consider this necessary.

The Contracting Authority shall not be liable for any costs or expenses incurred by any candidate or tenderer in connection with the completion and return of the information requested in this Contract Notice, or in the completion or submission of any tender, irrespective of the outcome of the competition or if the competition is cancelled or postponed.
All dates, time periods and values specified in this notice are provisional and the Contracting Authority reserves the right to change these.
Transparency: The Contracting Authority is subject to the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and the Environmental Information Regulations 2004 (EIR) and may be required to disclose information received in the course of this procurement under FOIA or the EIR.

In addition, and in accordance with the UK Government's policies on transparency, the contracting authority intends to publish procurement documentation and the text of any resulting contractual arrangements, subject to possible redactions at the discretion of the Contracting Authority.

Any redactions, whether in relation to information requests under FOIA, the EIR or policies on transparency will be in accordance with those grounds prescribed under the Freedom of Information Act. If and when this requirement is offered to tender, this will be done via electronic means using the internet. Midlands and Lancashire CSU is conducting this procurement exercise as a central purchasing body for another NHS body with whom the successful bidder(s) will enter into contracts for the supply of the services.

Any other public-sector body detailed within this notice, wishing to access the contract may do so only with permission from the contracting NHS body.
